verses.text: Then the kingdom of heaven will be like ten virgins, who took their lamps and went out to meet the bridegroom.
verses.comment: The parable compares the kingdom to a wedding procession, echoing Old Testament imagery of Israel as the bride and God as the groom (e.g., Ps 45:14). The theme of anticipation for the coming of Christ is central here.

verses.text: Five of them were foolish, and five were wise.
verses.comment: The division between wise and foolish echoes Christ's teaching in the Sermon on the Mount and wisdom literature (Prov 13:9), illustrating a call to readiness and discernment.

verses.text: For when the foolish took their lamps, they took no oil with them.
verses.comment: Oil symbolizes the spiritual preparation and perseverance required to enter the kingdom. The wise are prepared not merely outwardly, but also inwardly.

verses.text: But the wise took flasks of oil with their lamps.
verses.comment: The oil can also be read as a symbol of faith and works. The wise take extra precaution, showing that watchfulness and works sustain the light entrusted to them.

verses.text: As the bridegroom was delayed, they all became drowsy and fell asleep.
verses.comment: The delay highlights the mystery of the timing of Christ's return and the patience required (cf. 2 Pet 3:9). The sleep shows human frailty but not necessarily condemnation.

verses.text: But at midnight there was a cry, ‘Here is the bridegroom! Come out to meet him.’
verses.comment: The coming at midnight signifies the unexpected return of Christ. The 'cry' resembles the final trumpet—linking to 1 Thess 4:16.

verses.text: Then all those virgins rose and trimmed their lamps.
verses.comment: Trimming the lamps is a call to readiness—being spiritually prepared at all times (see Luke 12:35).

verses.text: The foolish said to the wise, ‘Give us some of your oil, for our lamps are going out.’
verses.comment: Spiritual preparation cannot be borrowed at the last moment. Each must cultivate their own faith and works.

verses.text: But the wise answered, saying, ‘Perhaps there will not be enough for us and for you. Go rather to those who sell, and buy some for yourselves.’
verses.comment: Responsibility for preparation is personal. The wise cannot give their preparedness to others.

verses.text: While they were going to buy, the bridegroom came, and those who were ready went in with him to the wedding banquet, and the door was shut.
verses.comment: Entrance into the kingdom is reserved for the prepared. The wedding banquet here recalls the heavenly feast (Rev 19:9). The shutting of the door echoes the finality of judgment (Matt 22:13).

verses.text: Afterward, the other virgins came, also, saying, ‘Lord, Lord, open to us.’
verses.comment: The plea ‘Lord, Lord’ echoes Jesus' teaching about the necessity of truly knowing Him, not just external profession (Matt 7:21).

verses.text: But he answered, ‘Truly, I say to you, I do not know you.’
verses.comment: A warning: relationship and obedience are required, not mere words. The phrase echoes His pronouncement in Matt 7:23.

verses.text: Keep watch therefore, for you know neither the day nor the hour.
verses.comment: A direct exhortation by Jesus to remain vigilant, as the timing of His return is unknowable—linking to His prior teaching (Matt 24:42).

verses.text: For it will be like a man going on a journey, who called his servants and entrusted to them his possessions.
verses.comment: This begins the Parable of the Talents, another image of the kingdom—a man (a Christ figure) entrusts his servants with responsibilities.

verses.text: To one he gave five talents, to another two, to another one, each according to his ability. Then he went away.
verses.comment: Distribution is according to ability. ‘Talents’ were large sums—here symbolic of gifts entrusted by God. Cf. Paul’s teaching about spiritual gifts (Rom 12:6).

verses.text: Immediately, he who had received the five talents went and traded with them, and made five more.
verses.comment: The faithful use of entrusted gifts leads to increase. This reflects fruitfulness in Christian life.

verses.text: In the same way, the one who had two talents gained two more.
verses.comment: Every servant is called to faithfulness with what is given, irrespective of the specific amount.

verses.text: But the one who had received the one talent went and dug in the ground and hid his master's money.
verses.comment: Neglecting gifts out of fear or laziness leads to loss—the talent is buried, not multiplied.

verses.text: After a long time the master of those servants returned and settled accounts with them.
verses.comment: Pointing to the final judgment, when all will give account to Christ for stewardship (Rom 14:12).

verses.text: And he who had received the five talents came forward, bringing five more, saying, ‘Master, you delivered to me five talents; see, I have made five more.’
verses.comment: Faithfulness in small things reveals one’s readiness for greater responsibility (Luke 16:10).

verses.text: His master said to him, ‘Well done, good and faithful servant. You have been faithful over little; I will set you over much. Enter into the joy of your master.’
verses.comment: This divine commendation suggests reward for faithfulness, not based on the magnitude of gifts, but on loyalty and stewardship.

verses.text: He also who had received the two talents came forward, saying, ‘Master, you delivered to me two talents; see, I have made two more.’
verses.comment: Again, the principle is that what matters is faithfulness with what has been entrusted, not comparison to others.

verses.text: His master said to him, ‘Well done, good and faithful servant. You have been faithful over little; I will set you over much. Enter into the joy of your master.’
verses.comment: The exact commendation to both faithful servants shows the justice of the master (Christ) in rewarding all acts of faithfulness equally.

verses.text: Then he who had received the one talent came forward, saying, ‘Master, I knew you to be a hard man, reaping where you did not sow, and gathering where you did not scatter seed.’
verses.comment: The unfaithful servant blames the master and shows a lack of trust; this reveals his real problem is not inability, but a wrong heart.

verses.text: So I was afraid, and I went and hid your talent in the ground. Here, you have what is yours.
verses.comment: Fear leads to inaction. Hiding what is given rather than living it out leads to no increase.

verses.text: But his master answered, ‘You wicked and lazy servant! You knew that I reap where I have not sown, and gather where I did not scatter?
verses.comment: The master condemns the servant’s laziness and abdication of responsibility, a spiritual warning against spiritual sloth.

verses.text: Then you ought to have invested my money with the bankers, and at my coming I should have received what was my own with interest.
verses.comment: At least minimal effort would have produced some result. Even small acts of faithfulness matter before God.

verses.text: So take the talent from him and give it to him who has the ten talents.
verses.comment: Those who properly use what is given will receive more. There is a spiritual principle here about God’s economy of grace and responsibility.

verses.text: For to everyone who has will more be given, and he will have an abundance. But from him who has not, even what he has will be taken away.
verses.comment: Faith and works, if exercised, increase; neglect causes loss. This principle is repeated elsewhere.

verses.text: And throw that worthless servant into the outer darkness. In that place there will be weeping and gnashing of teeth.’
verses.comment: ‘Outer darkness’ is a strong image for exclusion from the kingdom. Jesus uses this phrase repeatedly for final judgment.

verses.text: When the Son of Man comes in his glory, and all the angels with him, then he will sit on his glorious throne.
verses.comment: This alludes to Daniel 7:13–14, identifying Jesus as the glorious Son of Man, a divine title and a claim to divinity.

verses.text: All the nations will be gathered before him, and he will separate them one from another, as a shepherd separates the sheep from the goats.
verses.comment: Christ is pictured as both Shepherd and Judge, echoing Ezekiel and John’s Gospel—another implicit claim to divinity and universal judgment.

verses.text: He will set the sheep at his right hand, but the goats at the left.
verses.comment: The right hand is a place of honor. The sorting signifies the division between the righteous and the wicked.

verses.text: Then the King will say to those at his right hand, ‘Come, you who are blessed by my Father, inherit the kingdom prepared for you from the foundation of the world.
verses.comment: The kingdom is a prepared reality; predestined for the righteous. Points to the eternal plan of God (Eph 1:4).

verses.text: For I was hungry and you gave me food, I was thirsty and you gave me drink, I was a stranger and you welcomed me,
verses.comment: Jesus intimately associates Himself with ‘the least’—identifying Himself with the needy. Radical implications for faith and works.

verses.text: I was naked and you clothed me; I was sick and you visited me; I was in prison and you came to me.’
verses.comment: Works of mercy are emphasized as essential ways to serve Christ Himself.

verses.text: Then the righteous will answer him, saying, ‘Lord, when did we see you hungry and feed you, or thirsty and give you drink?
verses.comment: The righteous are surprised—their works of mercy were done humbly, not expecting reward.

verses.text: And when did we see you a stranger and welcome you, or naked and clothe you?
verses.comment: Continues the humility of the righteous; charity is performed for God without self-congratulation.

verses.text: And when did we see you sick or in prison and visit you?’
verses.comment: Sums up the list; even the lowliest acts are counted as serving Christ Himself.

verses.text: And the King will answer them, ‘Truly, I say to you, as you did it to one of the least of these my brethren, you did it to me.’
verses.comment: Jesus here claims for Himself a divine and mystical unity with believers—every act done to others is done to Him.

verses.text: Then he will say to those on his left hand, ‘Depart from me, you cursed, into the eternal fire prepared for the devil and his angels.
verses.comment: Eternal fire is not created for humanity but for fallen angels—yet those who reject grace are sent there by their own choices.

verses.text: For I was hungry and you gave me no food, I was thirsty and you gave me no drink,
verses.comment: The failure to perform works of mercy manifests a heart not transformed by Christ.

verses.text: I was a stranger and you did not welcome me, naked and you did not clothe me, sick and in prison and you did not visit me.’
verses.comment: A failure of love for Christ present in the needy is the ground for the condemnation.

verses.text: Then they also will answer, saying, ‘Lord, when did we see you hungry or thirsty or a stranger or naked or sick or in prison, and did not serve you?’
verses.comment: Both groups call Jesus 'Lord', indicating some external knowledge, but only those who served with love inherit the kingdom.

verses.text: Then he will answer them, saying, ‘Truly, I say to you, as you did not do it to one of the least of these, you did not do it to me.’
verses.comment: The link between charity and salvation is explicit; works done to or withheld from others are ultimately done to—or withheld from—Christ Himself.

verses.text: And these will go away into eternal punishment, but the righteous into eternal life.
verses.comment: Jesus clearly teaches the reality of eternal destinies. Both reward and punishment are everlasting; works have an ultimate eschatological consequence.
